title: Vandals target Newcastle's Byker Grove setting where Islamic school is due to open
text:
Vandals target Newcastle's Byker Grove setting where Islamic school is due to open 15:30, 1 Aug 2016 15:35, 1 Aug 2016 By Kathryn Riddell Fears have been raised about the vandalism at the Bishop's Palace buildings in Benwell, Newcastle, which was the setting of Byker Grove Shares Get daily news by email The former Bishop's Palace buildings, now part of the Bahr Academy 
The setting of TV hit Byker Grove, which is due to become an Islamic school, has been targeted by vandals. 
The windows in the former Bishop’s Palace buildings, now part of the Bahr Academy, were smashed between Thursday night and Friday morning. 
When Dipu Ahad, Elswick ward councillor, went to pray at the Benwell building at midday , he found that all the windows had been put out. 
Coun Ahad said although no one is sure why the building was targeted, he suspects it was an Islamophobic attack. 
“All the windows are smashed, causing considerable damage to a room used for Friday prayers. Nobody could pray,” he said. 
“It’s a sad situation, it looks like it is Islamophobic. There’s been a rise in hate crime, especially after Brexit, and people from minority communities are on edge. 
“It’s not the first time the building’s been attacked, someone once put a pig’s head inside.” Councillor Dipu Ahad 
Police officers were called to the scene but a Northumbria Police spokesperson was unable to confirm if the incident was being treated as a hate crime. 
A spokesperson said: “We got a call at 1.20pm on Friday to the Mitre in Benwell Lane, Newcastle to reports of a burglary. “A number of windows had been smashed. Police inquiries are ongoing.” 
The grade II-listed building was turned into a pub called The Mitre in the 1970s before becoming famous as the children’s TV youth club. 
Most recently, the building was bought in 2012, in a bid to set up an Islamic faith school and prayer centre for Muslims. The Newcastle-based Bahr Academy bought the site, which includes Benwell Towers and Welburn House, for £400,000 four years ago. 
It hopes to establish a school for 340 boys and girls between 11 and 16 as well as a community building, coffee shop and events space open at weekends. The former Bishop's Palace buildings, now part of the Bahr Academy 
Built in 1831 by architect John Dobson, the property was home to the bishops of Newcastle in the late 1800s, before being used as a fire station during the Second World War. 
After it was converted into a pub and restaurant, it was then turned into the TV set where Byker Grover was filmed for 17 years. 
Geordie duo Ant and Dec, who started their careers on Byker Grove, admitted in 2014 that they had tried to buy the buildings to turn them into a performing arts centre, but their bid was unsuccessful. 
The new school will be for young people who want to become Islamic scholars and clerics.
